        "Title": "LGAs In Anambra State Under High Flood Risk \u2013 NEMA DG",
        "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots. I want to use this opportunity to call on our revered traditional rulers, the clergy, opinion leaders, women and youth groups and the media in Anambra State to support proactive measures that will avert the negative impacts of the floods during the 2024 rainy season.\n\u201cI find it necessary to stress that management of disaster risk in contemporary times is hinged on community participation, leaving no one behind. As we always emphasize at NEMA, \u2018\u2018disaster management is everyone\u2019s business\u2019\u2019.\nWe must work together to safeguard communities at risk, protect critical infrastructure and support uninterrupted socio-economic activities in Anambra State. It is not by accident that NEMA selected Anambra State, the Light of the nation for this event. It is in recognition of the status of Anambra State as a focal point for exchange of goods and services and positive ideas that will permeate the entire South East region, Nigeria and beyond.\n\u201cI urge you to accord this event the very serious attention it deserves in consideration of the identified vulnerability of the populations especially in those Local Government Areas and communities at risk of flooding during the year. It is my hope that today\u2019s event will go a long way in reducing the impacts of the annually recurring floods and to safeguard the private and communal and livelihoods of the good people of Anambra State. This is the guaranteed path of driving socio economic growth and development in line with the renewed hope agenda of the Federal Government under the stewardship of His Excellency, President Bola Ahmed, Tinubu, GCFR.\u201d\nThe NEMA DG commended Governor Soludo for all the measures put in place by the State Government to reduce the occurrence of those avoidable losses in the State.\nOn his part, the Governor of Anambra State, Professor Soludo, who spoke through his Deputy, Dr Onyekachukwu Ibezim described the sensitization as apt as Anambra has continued to experience flood disaster each year causing it various degrees of loss, assuring that the government will collaborate NEMA and the State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, to ensure that people in prone areas in the state are well enlightened to avoid casualties and preventable damages.\nThe Governor who appreciated the federal government for always coming to the aid of the state during flooding, pleaded for more assistance in the aspect of bringing permanent solution to flooding through construction of dams and other necessary interventions.\nThe Executive Secretary, SEMA, Paul Odenigbo, said,\u201cThe Anambra State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, in collaboration with its federal counterpart, NEMA, and other relevant partners such as International Organisation on Migration, IOM, the Nigerian Red Cross, Civil Society Organisations and the Ministries of Health, Environment and Utilities have continued to engage in serious public awareness campaigns, to enlighten and sensitize stakeholders of the flood prone communities on the coming heavy downpour and its consequential flooding.\u201d\nUmar gave the assurance during her visit to Governor Chukwuma Soludo at the government house.\nMeanwhile, speaking earlier during her visit to Governor Soludo at the government house, the NEMA DG, called for the set up of Local Emergency Management Committees, LEMCs, in every Local Government Area with predictable funding to manage disasters together with traditional institutions and community volunteers, even as she galvanized support for persons affected by disasters before the arrival of external assistance.",

        "Title": "Flooding: NDDC begins construction of emergency shelters in 9 states",
        "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on implementing a regional flood disaster emergency response strategy.\nHe said that the Niger Delta was faced with an existential threat due to climate change, which could potentially devastate the region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka, Director of Environmental Control and Protection at NDDC, said that the workshop served as a platform for sharing knowledge, understanding best practices and adopting innovative strategies.\nHe emphasized that the adoption of innovative strategies would strengthen emergency response mechanisms for sustainable recovery post-flood disasters.\n\u201cInstalling water level gauges and sensors strategically around river systems will provide early flood warning.\n\u201cThese early warning will facilitate the timely evacuation of people before considerable havoc is done,\u201dhe said.\nOn his part, Prof. Andrew Obafemi, former National President of the Nigeria Cartographic Association, stressed the importance of sharing information and data to reduce flooding effects.\nHe recommenced the Niger Delta Environmental Survey plan as a crucial project to develop a reliable data bank for addressing flooding in the NDDC states.\nNAN / Foluke Ibitomi",

        "Title": "DRC, Burundi Borders face floods",
        "Full_Content": "Congolese and Burundian people pile onto this tractor and cross a 4km stretch of road flooded by Lake Tanganyika to reach the Kamvinvira border post between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi.\nFor more than six months, passengers have been charged between 2,000 and 5,000 FC to travel in heavy trucks or Land Cruiser jeeps to the border.\nFor those with less financial means, canoes costing 2,000 FC offer a solution.\nSafi Mugoli, a resident of Uvira on her way to Bujumbura, describes the current situation as catastrophic and unprecedented.\n\u201cThe road to the border is under water, so we cross by canoes or farming tractors. Sometimes we fall into the water and risk drowning. We\u2019re asking the State to help us with this customs road.\u201d\nFaced with this suffering, more and more people are calling on the Congolese government to urgently find a solution to ease traffic between the two countries and help local residents, especially small traders.\n\u201cWe sleep under tents with the children, we suffer a lot because we have nowhere to go. Even to go to the market, we have to take a canoe. If you don\u2019t have money, you have to swim. The women are suffering from infections and we\u2019re desperate.\u201d\nThe South Kivu provincial government, through its spokesman, acknowledged the consequences of the rising water levels at the border.\n\u201cThere were pillars already built that were submerged every time the water rose and blocked the work.\nA bridge is under construction to allow regular crossings. What has been done at Kamvinvira can also be done at Sange, so we\u2019re not standing still and are always looking for solutions. As long as the government is present, solutions will always be found.\u201d\nAs the provincial government seeks a solution to this problem, the Kamvinvira border remains the main access route to Bujumbura for many travellers, as Burundi has closed its other borders with Rwanda.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

environmental conservation in Benue and other parts of Nigeria.\nAccording to Prof Utsev, the project is a shining example of what can be achieved when government at all levels, agencies, private sector and local communities come together with a shared purpose.\nHe expressed hope that the project will not only protect the environment and infrastructure but also safeguard the lives and livelihoods of countless individuals who call the area a home.\nSenator Akume acknowledged the support of the Benue State government and its people for ensuring the successful execution of the project and called on the host communities to ensure that the infrastructure remain resilient and effective to tackle future challenges.\nHe appealed to Benue people to continue to pray and support the policies and programmes of President Bola Ahmed Tinubu to derive more benefits.\nBenue State Governor Reverend Father Hyacinth Alia represented by his Deputy Barrister Sam Odeh said the project was not just a necessity but a beacon of hope given the flood that has continued to ravage the area and thanked the Federal Government for its support and steps being taken to address flooding in Benue         "Title": "INEC To Replace Election Materials Damaged By Flood In Edo State",
        "Full_Content": "The Chairman, Independent National Electoral Commission, Prof. Mahmood Yakubu, on Thursday, assured the people of Edo State that the state governorship election slated for September 21 will go ahead despite the damage to the commission\u2019s office in the state.\nThe commission\u2019s state office in Benin, Edo state capital was recently submerged in water when heavy downpour flooded the office destroying vital election hardware, machines such as the Bimodal Voter Accreditation Machines (BVAS), documents and other materials.\nProf. Yakubu, while on an inspection visit to Benin to assess the level and impact of destruction at the state\u2019s INEC office said all facilities damaged by the flood will be replaced ahead of the September 21 governorship election.\n\u201cWe are here to see for ourselves what happened to our facilities following the unexpected torrential rainfall and flooding. We thank God that no life was lost, and no injuries sustained. But we want to assure you that despite the extensive damage, we will recover to conduct the governorship election in September\u201d.\nProf Yakubu said the commission would salvage some equipment from neighboring states to replace any shortfall and ensure the successful conduct of the election.\nHe assured Edo people that the ongoing Continuous Voter Registration, CVR, would continue despite the setback while promising to be more strategic in dealing with flood going forward.\nYakubu, ordered the deployment of more voter registration machines to some of the registration centres in Edo state for the ongoing Continuous Voter Registration (CVR) and commended the mass turnout of prospective registrants at different centres in the state.\nHe assured that INEC would do everything possible to make the process seamless.\nAt the Western Boys Secondary School, Ward 2, Ikpoba Okha LGA, registration centre, Yakubu directed that two additional Bimodal Voter Accreditation Systems, BVAS, machines be mobilized to cater for the large number of registrants.\n\u201cThe most important thing is for us to expedite the process. So what we have decided now is that tomorrow there will be two additional machines to this centre, to make it five machines.\n\u201cThere are two queues. One is for registration, the other one is for transfer and collection of cards. So they are going to reorganise the queues. But I have seen the numbers here, and one of the solutions is to increase the number of machines to this centre,\u201dhe said.\nProf. Yakubu directed that additional registration machines be deployed to the INEC Ikpoba Okha LGA Office centre. He also monitored the exercise at Eweka Primary School in Use Ward 3, Egor LGA.\nThe INEC Chairman, however, warned the staff of the commission against falling prey to any form of inducement before registering prospective voters during the exercise.\nOn complaints that some political parties were trying to hijack the exercises in the favour of their supporters, Yakubu said that the commission would be meeting with the state commissioner of Police and other security agencies in the state to address the concern.\n\u201cMy message consistently is that all the staff engaged in the registration, whether they are ad hoc staff or regular staff, should know that no one should collect money from any Nigerian who comes to register or transfer or request for replacement of cards.\n\u201cThis is a service paid for by the federal government of Nigeria and it must be respected. Where we catch any staff involved in this act, that staff will be dealt with, whether the staff is regular staff or ad hoc staff,\u201dYakubu said.\nEarlier, some of the prospective registrants in the queue who commended INEC for the exercise urged the commission to mobilize more registration machines to fast-track the registration process.\nMrs. Sliver Angela and Mr Oluwasegun Oketoki at the registration centre located at INEC Ikpoba Okha LGA Office, who said they came out as early as 5 am to register, called for the deployment of more machines to the centre to speed up the registration process.\n\u201cMost of us came here since 5.30.         "Full_Content": "Tens of thousands of students in Somalia\u2019s central Hiran region have been forced to stay out of schools after heavy rains flooded the institutions.\nAccording to Somali education officials, more than 37,000 students in this region in central Somalia are no longer in school due to the impact of recent flooding.\nThe area has been battered by heavy rains resulting in severe flooding in schools.\nParents are worried about how the disruption of education will affect their children\u2019s performance in the upcoming national examinations, and the floods also raised concerns of local teachers about the long-term impact on the education.\n\u201cThe learning materials have been destroyed and the classrooms have been damaged. It will be very difficult to recover, because most of the students have been displaced too far away locations, and it will be hard to bring them back and resume lessons,\u201dsaid Elmi Hashi Dhalin, a teacher in Somalia.\nParents of the affected students have been appealing to the government to intervene.\n\u201cThere is no learning here for the children. There is water everywhere. As parents, we are calling upon the Ministry of Education to establish schools in higher grounds, so that when the flooding season comes, students can continue their learning activities,\u201dBarre Ali Gedi, a student parent.\nLast year, the Somali government organized special exams after similar incidents of flooding disrupted the exam timetable.\nOfficials say they will do all they can to help.\n\u201cThe students in this region always have the worry of not taking part in the examination exercise despite hard work and preparation due to the flood havoc. We hope that will not happen again this year, \u201csaid Mustaf Osman Mohamud, director of education of the Beledweyn District in Somalia.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

        "Title": "Flooding: Wike orders reconstruction of Dogon Gada bridge \u2013 Coordinator",
        "Full_Content": "The Minister of the Nigerian Federal Capital Territory (FCT), Mr Nyesom Wike, has given a matching order for the immediate reconstruction of Dogon Gada box culvert in Lokogoma village, Abuja.\nThe Coordinator, Abuja Metropolitan Management Council (AMMC), Mr Felix Obuah, made this known in Abuja, during the 2024 Flood Risk Assessment and Community Awareness Campaign.\nThe campaign was organized by the FCT Emergency Management Department in collaboration with emergency management stakeholders.\nThe culvert was on the access road that linked over 3,000 residents of Lokogoma village, popularly known as Dogon Gada community to Ring Road II.\nThe FCT Emergency Management Department had on April 7, barricaded the box culvert, which had collapsed, to avert loss of lives.\nThe community loses their loved ones to flooding while trying to cross the culvert during the rainy season, due to its low elevation and prone to flooding.\nObuah said that the construction of the bridge would commence immediately after the engineering department concluded their structural designs and other technical requirements.\nHe assured the community that FEMD was taking necessary action to ensure that no life was lost to flooding in FCT throughout the 2024 rainy season.\n\u201cThe minister has given a matching order that the construction of the bride should commence with immediate effect.\n\u201cAs I speak to you, any moment from now work will commence. The engineering process has begun already for the speedy construction of the bridge,\u201dhe said.\nThe coordinator pointed out that human action has an impact on the environment, exposing it to varying degrees of flood risk.\nHe explained that the exercise was a preparedness and awareness campaign to sensitize residents against actions that would predispose communities to flood.\n\u201cI assured FCT residents that with the proactive measure being taken by FEMD and other stakeholders, no life will be lost in 2024 to flooding in 2024.\n\u201cWe must, therefore, continue to strengthen our collaboration towards flood prevention and mitigation,\u201dObuah said.\nEarlier, acting Director-General, FEMD, Mr Mohammed Sabo, said that the flood risk assessment and awareness campaign was part of strategies to strengthen disaster risk reduction.\nSabo said that other flood prone communities would also be sensitized to mobilize residents to take proactive steps towards preventing loss of lives to flood.\nHe added that the flood risk assessment would enable FEMD to assess interventions that worked and areas that need additional interventions to prevent flooding.\nAlso, Mr Florence Wenegieme, Director, Forecasting, Response and Mitigation, said that the bridge had taken many lives over the years during the rainy season.\nWenegiene explained that the people were killed by the flood because they tried to cross the flooded bridge against warnings by FEMD and local divers stationed at the bridge.\nMr Christopher Maikalangu, Chairman, Abuja Municipal Area Council, thanked Wike for the prompt intervention to prevent more people from dying from flooding along the bridge.\nHe said that the distance from the community to Ring Road II was 800 metres, but the residents had to travel five to six kilometres through alternative routes to get to the ring road.\nThe leader of the community, Mr Irimiya Kanpani, who could not hide his excitement over the minister\u2019s approval for the recommendation of the collapsed bridge described it as a huge relief,\n\u201cNow I can go to sleep knowing that the minister will fulfil his promise and my people will be safe.         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka, emphasized that the adoption of innovative strategies would strengthen emergency response mechanisms for sustainable recovery post-flood disasters.\n\u201cInstalling water level gauges and sensors The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka,         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions.         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to         "Title": "Flooding: NDDC begins construction of emergency shelters in 9 states",
        "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on implementing a regional flood disaster emergency response strategy.\nHe said that the Niger Delta was faced with an existential threat due to climate change, which could potentially devastate the region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka,         "Title": "LGAs In Anambra State Under High Flood Risk \u2013 NEMA DG",
        "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots. I want to use this opportunity to call on our revered traditional rulers, the clergy, opinion leaders, women and youth groups and the media in Anambra State to support proactive measures that will avert the negative impacts of the floods during the 2024 rainy season.\n\u201cI find it necessary to stress that management of disaster risk in contemporary times is hinged on community participation, leaving no one behind. As we always emphasize at NEMA, \u2018\u2018disaster management is everyone\u2019s business\u2019\u2019.\nWe must work together to safeguard communities at risk, protect critical infrastructure and support uninterrupted socio-economic activities in Anambra State. It is not by accident that NEMA selected Anambra State, the Light of the nation for this event. It is in recognition of the status of Anambra State as a focal point for exchange of goods and services and positive ideas that will permeate the entire South East region, Nigeria and beyond.\n\u201cI urge you to accord this event the very serious attention it deserves in consideration of the identified vulnerability of the populations especially in those Local Government Areas and communities at risk of flooding during the year. It is my hope that today\u2019s event will go a long way in reducing the impacts of the annually recurring floods and to safeguard the private and communal and livelihoods of the good people of Anambra State. This is the guaranteed path of driving socio economic growth and development in line with the renewed hope agenda of the Federal Government under the stewardship of His Excellency, President Bola Ahmed, Tinubu, GCFR.\u201d\nThe NEMA DG commended Governor Soludo for all the measures put in place by the State Government to reduce the occurrence of those avoidable losses in the State.\nOn his part, the Governor of Anambra State, Professor Soludo, who spoke through his Deputy, Dr Onyekachukwu Ibezim described the sensitization as apt as Anambra has continued to experience flood disaster each year causing it various degrees of loss, assuring that the government will collaborate NEMA and the State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, to ensure that people in prone areas in the state are well enlightened to avoid casualties and preventable damages.\nThe Governor who appreciated the federal government for always coming to the aid of the state during flooding, pleaded for more assistance in the aspect of bringing permanent solution to flooding through construction of dams and other necessary interventions.\nThe Executive Secretary, SEMA, Paul Odenigbo, said,\u201cThe Anambra State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, in collaboration with its federal counterpart, NEMA, and other relevant partners such as International Organisation on Migration, IOM, the Nigerian Red Cross, Civil Society Organisations and the Ministries of Health, Environment and Utilities have continued to engage in serious public awareness campaigns, to enlighten and sensitize stakeholders of the flood prone communities on the coming heavy downpour and its consequential flooding.\u201d\nUmar gave the assurance during her visit to Governor Chukwuma Soludo at the government         "Keyword": "flood",
        "Published_time": "2024-07-03T20:38:20+01:00",
        "Title": "LGAs In Anambra State Under High Flood Risk \u2013 NEMA DG",
        "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots. temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots. I want to use this opportunity to call on our revered traditional rulers, the clergy, opinion leaders, women and youth groups and the media in Anambra State to support proactive measures that will avert the negative impacts of the floods during the 2024 rainy season.\n\u201cI find it necessary to stress that management of disaster risk in contemporary times is hinged on community participation, leaving no one behind. As we always emphasize at NEMA, \u2018\u2018disaster management is everyone\u2019s business\u2019\u2019.\nWe must work together to safeguard communities at risk, protect critical infrastructure and support uninterrupted socio-economic activities in Anambra State. It is not by accident that NEMA selected Anambra State, the Light of the nation for this event. It is in recognition of the status of Anambra State as a focal point for exchange of goods and services and positive ideas that will permeate the entire South East region, Nigeria and beyond.\n\u201cI urge you to accord this event the very serious attention it deserves in consideration of the identified vulnerability of the populations especially in those Local Government Areas and communities at risk of flooding during the year. It is my hope that today\u2019s event will go a long way in reducing the impacts of the annually recurring floods and to safeguard the private and communal and livelihoods of the good people of Anambra State. This is the guaranteed path of driving socio economic growth and development in line with the renewed hope agenda of the Federal Government under the stewardship of His Excellency, President Bola Ahmed, Tinubu, GCFR.\u201d\nThe NEMA DG commended Governor Soludo for all the measures put in place by the State Government to reduce the occurrence of those avoidable losses in the State.\nOn his part, the Governor of Anambra State, Professor Soludo, who spoke through his Deputy, Dr Onyekachukwu Ibezim described the sensitization as apt as Anambra has continued to experience flood disaster each year causing it various degrees of loss, assuring that the government will collaborate NEMA and the State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, to ensure that people in prone areas in the state are well enlightened to avoid casualties and preventable damages.\nThe Governor who appreciated the federal government for always coming to the aid of the state during flooding, pleaded for more assistance in the aspect of bringing permanent solution to flooding through construction of dams and other necessary interventions.\nThe Executive Secretary, SEMA, Paul Odenigbo, said,\u201cThe Anambra State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, in collaboration with its federal counterpart, NEMA, and other relevant partners such as International Organisation on Migration, IOM, the Nigerian Red Cross, Civil Society Organisations and the Ministries of Health, Environment and Utilities have continued to engage in serious public awareness campaigns, to enlighten and sensitize stakeholders of the flood prone communities on the coming heavy downpour and its consequential flooding.\u201d\nUmar gave the assurance during her visit to Governor Chukwuma Soludo at the government house.\nMeanwhile, speaking earlier during her visit to Governor Soludo at the government house, the NEMA DG, called for the set up of Local Emergency Management Committees, LEMCs, in every Local         "Title": "Flooding: NDDC begins construction of emergency shelters in 9 states",
        "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on implementing a regional flood disaster emergency response strategy.\nHe said that the Niger Delta was faced with an existential threat due to climate change, which could potentially devastate the region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka, Director of Environmental Control and Protection at NDDC, said that the workshop served as a platform for sharing knowledge, understanding best practices and adopting innovative strategies.\nHe emphasized that the adoption of innovative strategies would strengthen emergency response mechanisms for sustainable recovery post-flood disasters.\n\u201cInstalling water level gauges and sensors strategically around river systems will provide early flood warning.\n\u201cThese early warning will facilitate the timely evacuation of people before considerable havoc is done,\u201dhe said.\nOn his part, Prof. Andrew Obafemi, former National President of the Nigeria Cartographic Association, stressed the importance of sharing information and data to reduce flooding effects.\nHe recommenced the         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka, emphasized that the adoption of innovative strategies would strengthen emergency response mechanisms for sustainable recovery post-flood disasters.\n\u201cInstalling water level gauges and sensors The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka,         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards.
