Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions.         "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels.         "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to         "Title": "Flooding: NDDC begins construction of emergency shelters in 9 states",
        "Full_Content": "The Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) has commenced building emergency shelters across the nine Niger Delta states to aid flood victims.\nThe states are Abia, Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Edo, Imo, Ondo and Rivers.\nDr Samual Ogbuku, the Managing Director of NDDC, disclosed this at a one-day workshop in Port Harcourt on Tuesday, focusing on implementing a regional flood disaster emergency response strategy.\nHe said that the Niger Delta was faced with an existential threat due to climate change, which could potentially devastate the region and have an enormous social-economic impact.\n\u201cHence, the commission is currently building multi-purpose emergency shelters across the Niger Delta to provide assistance to flood victims.\n\u201cThese emergency shelters, designed to accommodate over 1,000 people, will serve as a temporary refuge during flood emergencies,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku disclosed that the facility in each of the states would be equipped with essential amenities such as school, hospital, cafeteria, police post, and recreation centre.\n\u201cWhen completed, these emergency shelters will provide temporary accommodation and necessary services to communities during emergencies.\n\u201cWe realized that displaced people often seek refuge in school buildings during floods, forcing schools to suspend academic activities at great cost,\u201dhe stressed.\nThe managing director said that the workshop, focused on enhancing resilience in mitigating flood disasters in the region, underscored NDDC\u2019s commitment to addressing the challenge.\nAccording to him, the flood mitigation was crucial, given the region\u2019s topography and proximity to water bodies that made it susceptible to frequent flooding.\n\u201cCoastal and riverine communities, situated in low-lying areas, are at significant risk, with data showing over 100 fatalities between January 2021 and April 2023 due to flooding.\n\u201cAs we approach the peak of the rainy season, urgent measures are necessary to minimize flood impact, with collaboration among organisations and communities essential in this effort,\u201dhe said.\nOgbuku urged for partnership with the local communities, state governments, non-governmental organisations and international partners to tackle the disaster.\nMr Onuoha Obeka,         "Title": "LGAs In Anambra State Under High Flood Risk \u2013 NEMA DG",
        "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots. I want to use this opportunity to call on our revered traditional rulers, the clergy, opinion leaders, women and youth groups and the media in Anambra State to support proactive measures that will avert the negative impacts of the floods during the 2024 rainy season.\n\u201cI find it necessary to stress that management of disaster risk in contemporary times is hinged on community participation, leaving no one behind. As we always emphasize at NEMA, \u2018\u2018disaster management is everyone\u2019s business\u2019\u2019.\nWe must work together to safeguard communities at risk, protect critical infrastructure and support uninterrupted socio-economic activities in Anambra State. It is not by accident that NEMA selected Anambra State, the Light of the nation for this event. It is in recognition of the status of Anambra State as a focal point for exchange of goods and services and positive ideas that will permeate the entire South East region, Nigeria and beyond.\n\u201cI urge you to accord this event the very serious attention it deserves in consideration of the identified vulnerability of the populations especially in those Local Government Areas and communities at risk of flooding during the year. It is my hope that today\u2019s event will go a long way in reducing the impacts of the annually recurring floods and to safeguard the private and communal and livelihoods of the good people of Anambra State. This is the guaranteed path of driving socio economic growth and development in line with the renewed hope agenda of the Federal Government under the stewardship of His Excellency, President Bola Ahmed, Tinubu, GCFR.\u201d\nThe NEMA DG commended Governor Soludo for all the measures put in place by the State Government to reduce the occurrence of those avoidable losses in the State.\nOn his part, the Governor of Anambra State, Professor Soludo, who spoke through his Deputy, Dr Onyekachukwu Ibezim described the sensitization as apt as Anambra has continued to experience flood disaster each year causing it various degrees of loss, assuring that the government will collaborate NEMA and the State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, to ensure that people in prone areas in the state are well enlightened to avoid casualties and preventable damages.\nThe Governor who appreciated the federal government for always coming to the aid of the state during flooding, pleaded for more assistance in the aspect of bringing permanent solution to flooding through construction of dams and other necessary interventions.\nThe Executive Secretary, SEMA, Paul Odenigbo, said,\u201cThe Anambra State Emergency Management Agency, SEMA, in collaboration with its federal counterpart, NEMA, and other relevant partners such as International Organisation on Migration, IOM, the Nigerian Red Cross, Civil Society Organisations and the Ministries of Health, Environment and Utilities have continued to engage in serious public awareness campaigns, to enlighten and sensitize stakeholders of the flood prone communities on the coming heavy downpour and its consequential flooding.\u201d\nUmar gave the assurance during her visit to Governor Chukwuma Soludo at the government         "Keyword": "flood",
        "Published_time": "2024-07-03T20:38:20+01:00",
        "Title": "LGAs In Anambra State Under High Flood Risk \u2013 NEMA DG",
        "Full_Content": "The Director General National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Zubaida Umar, has disclosed that 11 Local Government Areas in Anambra State: Ogbaru, Anambra East, Anambra West, Ayamelum, Idemili North, Onitsha North, Nnewi North, Idemili South, Onitsha South, Ihiala and Ekwusigo are under high and moderate flood risk, and these are already listed in the earlier NEMA communication to the Government of Anambra State.\nThe NEMA DG stated this in Awka, the state capital on Wednesday, during 2024 downscaling of flood early warning strategies for early actions to save lives and livelihoods during the rainy season in Anambra State.\nAccording to the NEMA Boss, \u201cThe devastating impacts of flood over the years especially that of 2012 and 2022 have served as a wakeup call to all tiers of Governments and their line Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs) to collaborate with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to manage disaster risks and associated hazards. In the recent past, lives have been lost, means of livelihood and infrastructure amounting to billions of Naira have been destroyed by floods. Our citizens have equally suffered injuries and lost their life savings due to unmitigated incidences of floods and secondary hazards.\nFrom North to South and East to West, straddling vast swathes of land, river banks, coastal areas, built up environment, farmlands, economic and industrial centers, floods have continually impacted negatively on Nigerian citizens. The rainfall and flood advisories contained in the Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) and Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) of the Nigerian Meteorological Agency and Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) respectively, have provided us valuable early warning alerts. Consequently, all of us are expected to take actions that will drastically reduce the adverse impacts of floods on the entire landscape and the Nigerian population, with emphasis to the most vulnerable persons living in communities identified to be at risk of inundation during the year.\nUmar, further stated that NIHSA has specifically stated that in 2024 148 LGAs in 31 States are predicted to be within the high flood risk areas while 249 LGAs in 35 States including FCT are considered to fall within the moderate flood risk areas.She added that the remaining 377 LGAs are forecasted for the low flood risk areas and these flood risk areas are presented with their degree of vulnerability to serve as a tool for governments at all levels to develop risk reduction measures to avert disaster losses during the rainy season.\nShe called on public and private institutions, humanitarian and non-governmental organizations to leverage on these early warnings to support the efforts of government institutions. Umar also urged sectors of agriculture and food security, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), education, health, transportation, protection and security, to set up mechanisms for disaster preparedness and risk reduction based on the early action strategies.\n\u201cIt is in this regard that the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) convened a two-day Experts Technical Meeting of relevant stakeholders in April, 2024 to review the NIMET SCP and the NIHSA AFO to develop early warning and mitigation strategies for Nigeria. An Emergency Coordination Forum (ECF) was also convened on the 7th of May in Abuja to analyze the disaster risk management implications of the SCP and AFO predictions. These events were to design and incorporate direct risk communication and engagement approaches to disseminate early warning messages for early actions at state, local government and community levels. This underscores the rationale for carrying out the sensitization exercises across the country as we flag off this event in Awka, Anambra State today.\n\u201cAs reflected in NEMA\u2019s flood incidence dashboard, Anambra State has in the past suffered severe flooding in terms of spatial coverage, severe losses and damage as well as fatalities. While sympathizing with the Government and good people of Anambra State over the unprecedented adverse effects of flood risks is the past years.\n\u201cAccordingly, I call on the State and Local Governments, Traditional institutions, faith based organizations, public and private institutions and relevant stakeholders to support NEMA in this initiative of downscaling flood early warning and mitigation messages to the grassroots.         "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent         "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this year.\nMultiple aid agencies warned last year of the impending disaster.\nSince then, Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema has said that 1 million of the 2.2 million hectares of his country\u2019s staple corn crop have been destroyed.\nMalawian President Lazarus Chakwera has appealed for $200 million in humanitarian assistance.\nThe 2.7 million rural folk struggling in Zimbabwe is not even the full picture.\nA nationwide crop assessment is underway and authorities are \u201cdreading\u201d the results, with the number needing help likely to skyrocket, said the WFP\u2019s Erdelmann.\nUSAID\u2019s Famine Early Warning System estimated that 20 million people would require food relief in southern Africa in the first few months of 2024.\nWith this year\u2019s harvest a write-off, millions in Zimbabwe, southern Malawi, Mozambique and Madagascar won\u2019t be able to feed themselves well into 2025.\nMany just won\u2019t get that help as aid agencies also have limited resources amid a global hunger crisis and a cut in humanitarian funding by governments.\nAs the WFP officials made their last visit to Mangwe, Ncube was already calculating how long the food might last her.\nShe said she hoped it would be long enough to avert her greatest fear, that her youngest child would slip into malnutrition even before his first birthday.\nAfrican news/Jide Johnson.",

        "Full_Content": "Morocco, where agriculture is a crucial sector, is heading for its sixth consecutive year of drought due to a drop in rainfall in recent months linked to climate change, Morocco\u2019s Minister of Equipment and Water, Nizar Baraka, said.\n\u201cWe have entered a critical phase after five consecutive years of drought that our country has never experienced before,\u201dsaid Mr Baraka at a press conference.\nRainfall has fallen by 67% in recent months compared with a year considered normal, and\u201cthe last three months (from October to December) show that we are heading for another year of drought\u201d,the minister added.\nIn Morocco, agriculture employs a third of the working-age population and accounts for 14% of the country\u2019s exports.\nWater stress in Morocco has been exacerbated by rising temperatures, which have increased water evaporation from dams.\nThe Ministry of Agriculture predicts an average temperature rise of 1.3 degrees Celsius by 2050.\nThe North African country\u2019s reservoirs are currently only 23.5% full, compared with 31% at the same time last year, which is\u201ca very dangerous situation\u201d,said Mr Baraka.\n\u201cOur hopes are high for the next three months, which are (usually) the rainiest in our country\u201d,he added.\nFailing that, local authorities in some regions will have to turn off the water supply, usually at night.\nIn the face of growing water stress, the authorities are betting on seawater desalination projects, such as the one due to start construction next month in Casablanca, the country\u2019s largest conurbation with over six million inhabitants.\nBy the end of 2027, Morocco plans to build seven desalination plants with a total capacity of 143 million cubic meters per year.\nThere are currently 12 desalination plants in the country, with a total capacity of 179.3 million cubic meters per year, according to official data.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

        "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched and beige.\nThe images also \u201cclearly depict a rapid change in the reservoir\u2019s surface area\u201d, Prof Brian Thomas, a hydrogeologist who has analysed satellite images for Nasa, said.\nThe suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent years.\n\u201cThe most difficult drought we have experienced in history is this year,\u201d Mr Wardi said.\n\u201cFor me, the current agricultural year is lost.\u201d\nHis ewes had stillbirths because         "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this year.\nMultiple aid agencies warned last year of the impending disaster.\nSince then, Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema has said that 1 million of the 2.2 million hectares of his country\u2019s staple corn crop have been destroyed.\nMalawian President Lazarus Chakwera has appealed for $200 million in humanitarian assistance.\nThe 2.7 million rural folk struggling in Zimbabwe is not even the full picture.\nA nationwide crop assessment is underway and authorities are \u201cdreading\u201d the results, with the number needing help likely to skyrocket, said the WFP\u2019s Erdelmann.\nUSAID\u2019s Famine Early Warning System estimated that 20 million people would require food relief in southern Africa in the first few months of 2024.\nWith this year\u2019s harvest a write-off, millions in Zimbabwe, southern Malawi, Mozambique and Madagascar won\u2019t be able to feed themselves well into 2025.\nMany just won\u2019t get that help as aid agencies also have limited resources amid a global hunger crisis and a cut in humanitarian funding by governments.\nAs the WFP officials made their last visit to Mangwe, Ncube was already calculating how long the food might last her.\nShe said she hoped it would be long enough to avert her greatest fear, that her youngest child would slip into malnutrition even before his first birthday.\nAfrican news/Jide Johnson.",

        "Full_Content": "Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema declared the drought a national disaster and emergency on Thursday, saying it had devastated food production and power generation, as the country struggles to recover a recent cholera epidemic.\nLike some of its neighbors, this southern African country is suffering from severe drought due to the El Nino phenomenon, which is worsening harsh weather conditions attributed in part to climate change.In a statement to the nation, Hichilema said he had asked security forces to focus more on food production. He said 84 of the country\u2019s 116 districts were affected by the prolonged drought and that authorities would take food from areas where there is a surplus and distribute it to areas in need.Additionally, Zambia plans to increase food imports and mobilizes UN agencies and local businesses to help. He added that the drought has destroyed about 1 million hectares of the 2.2 million hectares planted in corn, the staple crop.\u201cThis drought is having devastating consequences on many sectors such as agriculture, water availability, and energy supply, jeopardizing our national food security and the livelihoods of millions of people. \u201cDrought is expected to continue until March, affecting more than a million of our agricultural households,\u201d said Hichilema.Electricity production has not been spared, with the country expecting a deficit of around 430 megawatts \u201cpotentially reaching 520 megawatts by December\u201d, he said, due to the falling level water in the country\u2019s main source of hydroelectric power, the Kariba Dam, which it shares with its neighbor, Zimbabwe.To cope with this situation, the country will import electricity and ration the supply for its approximately 20 million inhabitants.Zambia was recently hit by one of its worst outbreaks of cholera, which killed more than 400 people and infected more than 10,000.Some Zambians, tired of the persistence of crises, have invented songs calling the coronavirus and cholera epidemics, as well as the current drought, a \u201dtriple tragedy\u201d, he said.Although many countries in southern Africa have not yet declared a national disaster, they are also in a dire situation due to the         "Full_Content": "Morocco, where agriculture is a crucial sector, is heading for its sixth consecutive year of drought due to a drop in rainfall in recent months linked to climate change, Morocco\u2019s Minister of Equipment and Water, Nizar Baraka, said.\n\u201cWe have entered a critical phase after five consecutive years of drought that our country has never experienced before,\u201dsaid Mr Baraka at a press conference.\nRainfall has fallen by 67% in recent months compared with a year considered normal, and\u201cthe last three months (from October to December) show that we are heading for another year of drought\u201d,the minister added.\nIn Morocco, agriculture employs a third of the working-age population and accounts for 14% of the country\u2019s exports.\nWater stress in Morocco has been exacerbated by rising temperatures, which have increased water evaporation from dams.\nThe Ministry of Agriculture predicts an average temperature rise of 1.3 degrees Celsius by 2050.\nThe North African country\u2019s reservoirs are currently only 23.5% full, compared with 31% at the same time last year, which is\u201ca very dangerous situation\u201d,said Mr Baraka.\n\u201cOur hopes are high for the next three months, which are (usually) the rainiest in our country\u201d,he added.\nFailing that, local authorities in some regions will have to turn off the water supply, usually at night.\nIn the face of growing water stress, the authorities are betting on seawater desalination projects, such as the one due to start construction next month in Casablanca, the country\u2019s largest conurbation with over six million inhabitants.\nBy the end of 2027, Morocco plans to build seven desalination plants with a total capacity of 143 million cubic meters per year.\nThere are currently 12 desalination plants in the country, with a total capacity of 179.3 million cubic meters per year, according to official data.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

        "Full_Content": "Riots erupted in Algerian desert city last weekend after months of water shortages left taps running dry and forced residents to queue to access water for their households.\nIn Tiaret, a central Algerian city of less than 200,000 located 155 miles (250 kilometers) southwest of Algiers protestors wearing balaclavas set tires aflame and set up make-shift barricades blocking roads to protest their water being rationed, according to pictures and videos circulating on social media.\nThe unrest followed demands from President bdelmajid Tebboune to rectify the suffering. At a council of ministers meeting last week, he implored his cabinet to implement \u201cemergency measures\u201d in Tiaret. Several government ministers were later sent to \u201cask for an apology from the population\u201d and to promise that access to drinking water would be restored.\nPolitical Implications and Climate Impact\nThe rioting comes as Tebboune is expected to vie for a second term as president of the oil-rich nation \u2014 Africa\u2019s largest by area. Northern Africa has been among the world\u2019s worst-hit regions by climate change. A multi-year drought has drained critical reservoirs and reduced the amount of rainfall that has historically replenished them.\nREAD ALSO: Thousands of Afghan children impacted by flash floods\nThe region, located on a semi-arid high desert plateau increasingly plagued by extreme heat, gets its water from three dammed reservoirs that are shrinking as temperatures spike and less rain falls.\nThe reservoirs have become less functional due to a \u201cdeath of volume\u201d and are reduced to 20% of their capacity, agricultural engineer Said Ouarad said.\nThe region\u2019s groundwater aquifers have for years not been able to recharge due to an absence of rain, he added.\nLong-term and Short-term Solutions\nAlgeria\u2019s long-term solution would be to pipe water from larger dams further north and south from Tiaret and shift to alternative supplies, including desalination plants that the country has heavily invested in.\nREAD ALSO: Extreme weather stirs cholera outbreaks in parts of east and southern Africa\nBut in the meantime, officials are trying to import water from nearby sources.         "Title": "Morocco Drought : Satellite Images Show Vital Reservoir Is Shrinking",
        "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl Massira Dam, which sits around halfway between Casablanca and Marrakesh, contains just 3% of the average amount of water that was there nine years ago, figures show.\nSix consecutive years of drought and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched and beige.\nThe images also \u201cclearly depict a rapid change in the reservoir\u2019s surface area\u201d, Prof Brian Thomas, a hydrogeologist who has analysed satellite images for Nasa, said.\nThe appearance of the water had also changed, he added, indicating shifts in land use and the flow of the river feeding the reservoir.\nBut the impact of the drought is not confined to the area around Al Massira \u2013 it stretches across the country.\nAgriculture accounts for just under 90% of water consumption in Morocco, according to World Bank data from 2020, and farmers have been suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent years.\n\u201cThe most difficult drought we have experienced in history is this year,\u201d Mr Wardi said.\n\u201cFor me, the current agricultural year is lost.\u201d\nHis ewes had stillbirths because of the lack of water and food available to sheep during the drought.\nEven the nearby wells fed by groundwater had little left in them, he said.\nA short drive to a nearby valley and the broader issue becomes visible as a river clearly affected by the drought comes into view.\nBBC/Jide Johnson.",

        "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this         "Title": "Morocco Drought : Satellite Images Show Vital Reservoir Is Shrinking",
        "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl Massira Dam, which sits around halfway between Casablanca and Marrakesh, contains just 3% of the average amount of water that was there nine years ago, figures show.\nSix consecutive years of drought and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched and beige.\nThe images also \u201cclearly depict a rapid change in the reservoir\u2019s surface area\u201d, Prof Brian Thomas, a hydrogeologist who has analysed satellite images for Nasa, said.\nThe appearance of the water had also changed, he added, indicating shifts in land use and the flow of the river feeding the reservoir.\nBut the impact of the drought is not confined to the area around Al Massira \u2013 it stretches across the country.\nAgriculture accounts for just under 90% of water consumption in Morocco, according to World Bank data from 2020, and farmers have been suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent         "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this year.\nMultiple aid agencies warned last year of the impending disaster.\nSince then, Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema has said that 1 million of the 2.2 million hectares of his country\u2019s staple corn crop have been destroyed.\nMalawian President Lazarus Chakwera has appealed for $200 million in humanitarian assistance.\nThe 2.7 million rural folk struggling in Zimbabwe is not even the full picture.\nA nationwide crop assessment is underway and authorities are \u201cdreading\u201d the results, with the number needing help likely to skyrocket, said the WFP\u2019s Erdelmann.\nUSAID\u2019s Famine Early Warning System estimated that 20 million people would require food relief in southern Africa in the first few months of 2024.\nWith this year\u2019s harvest a write-off, millions in Zimbabwe, southern Malawi, Mozambique and Madagascar won\u2019t be able to feed themselves well into 2025.\nMany just won\u2019t get that help as aid agencies also have limited resources amid a global hunger crisis and a cut in humanitarian funding by governments.\nAs the WFP officials made their last visit to Mangwe, Ncube was already calculating how long the food might last her.\nShe said she hoped it would be long enough to avert her greatest fear, that her youngest child would slip into malnutrition even before his first birthday.\nAfrican news/Jide Johnson.",

A multi-year drought has drained critical reservoirs and reduced the amount of rainfall that has historically replenished them.\nREAD ALSO: Thousands of Afghan children impacted by flash floods\nThe region, located on a semi-arid high desert plateau increasingly plagued by extreme heat, gets its water from three dammed reservoirs that are shrinking as temperatures spike and less rain falls.\nThe reservoirs have become less functional due to a \u201cdeath of volume\u201d and are reduced to 20% of their capacity, agricultural engineer Said Ouarad said.\nThe region\u2019s groundwater aquifers have for years not been able to recharge due to an absence of rain, he added.\nLong-term and Short-term Solutions\nAlgeria\u2019s long-term solution would be to pipe water from larger dams further north and south from Tiaret and shift to alternative supplies, including desalination plants that the country has heavily invested in.\nREAD ALSO: Extreme weather stirs cholera outbreaks in parts of east and southern Africa\nBut in the meantime, officials are trying to import water from nearby sources.         "Title": "Morocco Drought : Satellite Images Show Vital Reservoir Is Shrinking",
        "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl Massira Dam, which sits around halfway between Casablanca and Marrakesh, contains just 3% of the average amount of water that was there nine years ago, figures show.\nSix consecutive years of drought and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched and beige.\nThe images also \u201cclearly depict a rapid change in the reservoir\u2019s surface area\u201d, Prof Brian Thomas, a hydrogeologist who has analysed satellite images for Nasa, said.\nThe appearance of the water had also changed, he added, indicating shifts in land use and the flow of the river feeding the reservoir.\nBut the impact of the drought is not confined to the area around Al Massira \u2013 it stretches across the country.\nAgriculture accounts for just under 90% of water consumption in Morocco, according to World Bank data from 2020, and farmers have been suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent years.\n\u201cThe most difficult drought we have experienced in history is this year,\u201d Mr Wardi said.\n\u201cFor me, the current agricultural year is lost.\u201d\nHis ewes had stillbirths because         "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this year.\nMultiple aid agencies warned last year of the impending disaster.\nSince then, Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema has said that 1 million of the 2.2 million hectares of his country\u2019s staple corn crop have been destroyed.\nMalawian President Lazarus Chakwera has appealed for $200 million in humanitarian assistance.\nThe 2.7 million rural folk struggling in Zimbabwe is not even the full picture.\nA nationwide crop assessment is underway and authorities are \u201cdreading\u201d the results, with the number needing help likely to skyrocket, said the WFP\u2019s Erdelmann.\nUSAID\u2019s Famine Early Warning System estimated that 20 million people would require food relief in southern Africa in the first few months of 2024.\nWith this year\u2019s harvest a write-off, millions in Zimbabwe, southern Malawi, Mozambique and Madagascar won\u2019t be able to feed themselves well into 2025.\nMany just won\u2019t get that help as aid agencies also have limited resources amid a global hunger crisis and a cut in humanitarian funding by governments.\nAs the WFP officials made their last visit to Mangwe, Ncube was already calculating how long the food might last her.\nShe said she hoped it would be long enough to avert her greatest fear, that her youngest child would slip into malnutrition even before his first birthday.\nAfrican news/Jide Johnson.",

        "Full_Content": "Riots erupted in Algerian desert city last weekend after months of water shortages left taps running dry and forced residents to queue to access water for their households.\nIn Tiaret, a central Algerian city of less than 200,000 located 155 miles (250 kilometers) southwest of Algiers protestors wearing balaclavas set tires aflame and set up make-shift barricades blocking roads to protest their water being rationed, according to pictures and videos circulating on social media.\nThe unrest followed demands from President bdelmajid Tebboune to rectify the suffering.         "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent years.\n\u201cThe most difficult drought we have experienced in history is this year,\u201d Mr Wardi said.\n\u201cFor me, the current agricultural year is lost.\u201d\nHis ewes had stillbirths because         "Title": "Drought And Famine In Southern Africa Leave 20 Million Hunger",
        "Full_Content": "Delicately and with intense concentration, Zanyiwe Ncube poured her small share of precious golden cooking oil into a plastic bottle at a food aid distribution site deep in rural Zimbabwe.\nHer relief at the handout paid for by the U.S. government as her southern African country deals with a severe drought was tempered when aid workers gently broke the news that this would be their last visit.\nNcube and her 7-month-old son she carried on her back were among 2,000 people who received rations of cooking oil, sorghum, peas and other supplies in the Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe.\nThe food distribution is part of a programme funded by American aid agency USAID and rolled out by the United Nations\u2019 World Food Programme.\nThey\u2019re aiming to help some of the 2.7 million people in rural Zimbabwe threatened with hunger because of the drought that has enveloped large parts of southern Africa since late last year.\nIt has scorched the crops that tens of millions of people grow themselves and rely on to survive, helped by what should be the rainy season.\nThey can rely on their crops and the weather less and less.\nThe drought in Zimbabwe, neighbouring Zambia and Malawi has reached crisis levels.\nZambia and Malawi have declared national disasters. Zimbabwe could be on the brink of doing the same.\nIt has reached Botswana and Angola to the west, and Mozambique and Madagascar to the east.\nA year ago, much of this region was drenched by deadly tropical storms and floods.\nIt is in the midst of a vicious weather cycle: Damned by too much rain, then by not enough, it\u2019s a story of the climatic extremes that scientists say are becoming more frequent and more damaging, especially for the world\u2019s most vulnerable people.\nIn Mangwe, the young and the old lined up for food, some with donkey carts to carry home whatever they might get, others with wheelbarrows.\nThose waiting their turn sat on the dusty ground.\nNcube, 39, would normally be harvesting her crops now, food for her, her two children and a niece she also looks after.\nMaybe there would even be a little extra to sell. The driest February in Zimbabwe in her lifetime, according to the World Food Programme\u2019s seasonal monitor, put an end to that.\n\u201cWe have nothing in the fields, not a single grain. Everything has dried up,\u201d she said.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says there are \u201coverlapping crises\u201d of extreme weather in eastern and southern Africa, with both regions lurching between storms and floods and heat and drought in the last year.\nIn southern Africa, an estimated 9 million people, half of them children, need help in Malawi.\nMore than 6 million in Zambia, 3 million of them children, are impacted by the drought, UNICEF said. That\u2019s nearly half of Malawi\u2019s population and 30% of Zambia\u2019s.\nWhile man-made climate change has spurred more erratic weather globally, there is something else parching southern Africa this year.\nEl Ni\u00f1o, the naturally occurring climatic phenomenon that warms parts of the Pacific Ocean every two to seven years, has varied effects on the world\u2019s weather.\nIn southern Africa, it means below-average rainfall, sometimes drought, and is being blamed for the current situation.\nThe impact is more severe for people like those in Mangwe, where it\u2019s notoriously arid and people grow the cereal grain sorghum and pearl millet, crops that are drought resistant and offer a chance at harvests.\nThis year, even they failed to withstand the conditions.\nFrancesca Erdelmann, the World Food Programme\u2019s country director for Zimbabwe, said last year\u2019s harvest was bad, but this season is even worse.\n\u201cThis is not a normal circumstance,\u201d she said.\nThe first few months of the year are traditionally the \u201clean months\u201d when households run short as they wait for the new harvest.\nHowever, there is little hope for replenishment this year.\nMultiple aid agencies warned last year of the impending disaster.\nSince then, Zambian President Hakainde Hichilema has said that 1 million of the 2.2 million hectares of his country\u2019s staple corn crop have been destroyed.\nMalawian President Lazarus Chakwera has appealed for $200 million in humanitarian assistance.\nThe 2.7 million rural folk struggling in Zimbabwe is not even the full picture.\nA nationwide crop assessment is underway and authorities are \u201cdreading\u201d the results, with the number needing help likely to skyrocket, said the WFP\u2019s Erdelmann.\nUSAID\u2019s Famine Early Warning System estimated that 20 million people would require food relief in southern Africa in the first few months of 2024.\nWith this year\u2019s harvest a write-off, millions in Zimbabwe, southern Malawi, Mozambique and Madagascar won\u2019t be able to feed themselves well into 2025.\nMany just won\u2019t get that help as aid agencies also have limited resources amid a global hunger crisis and a cut in humanitarian funding by governments.\nAs the WFP officials made their last visit to Mangwe, Ncube was already calculating how long the food might last her.\nShe said she hoped it would be long enough to avert her greatest fear, that her youngest child would slip into malnutrition even before his first birthday.\nAfrican news/Jide Johnson.",

        "Full_Content": "Riots erupted in Algerian desert city last weekend after months of water shortages left taps running dry and forced residents to queue to access water for their households.\nIn Tiaret, a central Algerian city of less than 200,000 located 155 miles (250 kilometers) southwest of Algiers protestors wearing balaclavas set tires aflame and set up make-shift barricades blocking roads to protest their water being rationed, according to pictures and videos circulating on social media.\nThe unrest followed demands from President bdelmajid Tebboune to rectify the suffering. At a council of ministers meeting last week, he implored his cabinet to implement \u201cemergency measures\u201d in Tiaret. Northern Africa has been among the world\u2019s worst-hit regions by climate change. A multi-year drought has drained critical reservoirs and reduced the amount of rainfall that has historically replenished them.\nREAD ALSO: Thousands of Afghan children impacted by flash floods\nThe region, located on a semi-arid high desert plateau increasingly plagued by extreme heat, gets its water from three dammed reservoirs that are shrinking as temperatures spike and less rain falls.\nThe reservoirs have become less functional due to a \u201cdeath of volume\u201d and are reduced to 20% of their capacity, agricultural engineer Said Ouarad said.\nThe region\u2019s groundwater aquifers have for years not been able to recharge due to an absence of rain, he added.\nLong-term and Short-term Solutions\nAlgeria\u2019s long-term solution would be to pipe water from larger dams further north and south from Tiaret and shift to alternative supplies, including desalination plants that the country has heavily invested in.\nREAD ALSO: Extreme weather stirs cholera outbreaks in parts of east and southern Africa\nBut in the meantime, officials are trying to import water from nearby sources.         "Full_Content": "Morocco\u2019s second-largest reservoir that serves some of its major cities and has been central to farm irrigation is drying up, according to satellite images analysed.\nAl Massira Dam, which sits around halfway between Casablanca and Marrakesh, contains just 3% of the average amount of water that was there nine years ago, figures show.\nSix consecutive years of drought and climate change, which causes record temperatures that lead to more evaporation, have threatened water supplies across the North African nation and hit agriculture and the economy in general.\nThe satellite images were taken in the same month, March, over successive years from 2018 to 2024.\nThey show a stark transformation in the landscape, with areas that are normally green becoming parched and beige.\nThe images also \u201cclearly depict a rapid change in the reservoir\u2019s surface area\u201d, Prof Brian Thomas, a hydrogeologist who has analysed satellite images for Nasa, said.\nThe appearance of the water had also changed, he added, indicating shifts in land use and the flow of the river feeding the reservoir.\nBut the impact of the drought is not confined to the area around Al Massira \u2013 it stretches across the country.\nAgriculture accounts for just under 90% of water consumption in Morocco, according to World Bank data from 2020, and farmers have been suffering.\nAbdelmajid El Wardi cultivates cotton and wheat, as well as rearing sheep and goats, on his land to the east of Ain Aouda, near the capital, Rabat.\nBut he has reaped little in recent years.\n\u201cThe most difficult drought we have experienced in history is this year,\u201d Mr Wardi said.\n\u201cFor me, the current agricultural year is lost.\u201d\nHis ewes had stillbirths because
