        "Title": "Heatwave: Dermatologist advises Nigerians on safety measures",
        "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

        "Title": "Egypt plans power cuts due to heatwave",
        "Full_Content": "Egypt has announced a series of measures, including planned power cuts, to cope with the growing energy consumption caused by the intense heat wave sweeping the country.\nIn a televised address on 6thAugust, Prime Minister Mustafa al-Madbouly called on the private sector to take similar measures, saying that civil servants who do not work in a job in contact with the public will work from home one day a week for a month in order to relieve the electricity grids.\nTo cope with rising energy consumption across the country, planned power cuts are expected to last one or two hours a day at most, he added.\nThey are expected to continue until the end of the current heatwave, which has seen temperatures exceed 45 degrees this week in some parts of the country.\nThe government began implementing the cuts last week, urging residents not to use lifts at certain times of the day.\nThis measure sparked a wave of discontent on social networks, with many complaining that the power cuts, often at the hottest times of the day, lasted for more than two hours and occurred only once a week.\nEgypt\u2019s economy has been undermined by galloping inflation and repeated currency depreciations, which have affected purchasing power and the ability to import essential goods.\nA similar energy crisis during the presidency of Islamist Mohamed Morsi in 2013 sparked widespread anger and protests before he was deposed by the army.\nIn 2015, the Egyptian authorities had struck a deal with Germany\u2019s Siemens to build three major power plants, with investments estimated at six billion euros with the aim of doubling the country\u2019s electricity production.\nSince then, Egypt has had to contend with the depletion of its foreign exchange reserves and a growing debt, exacerbated in particular by Russia\u2019s invasion of Ukraine.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

        "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. So that\u2019s a better argument to put, rather than saying that heatwaves worsen hypertension.\u201d",

        "Title": "Heatwave: Dermatologist advises Nigerians on safety measures",
        "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

        "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. Pregnant women get dehydrated easily and quickly.\n\u201cFor pregnant women in their first trimester, extreme heat waves could cause changes in the system where the body is forming the baby.\n\u201cThis period is the time that the organs are formed, when the foetus is ill, there is a higher risk of miscarriage and early birth, which might make the outcome of the pregnancy unpalatable to the mother.\n\u201cFor the baby born prematurely, it causes more difficulty in care as cost and survival is always guarded depending on the age.\u201d\nThe don urged pregnant women during this period to work in a well-ventilated and cool environment and refrain from walking in the sun.\nHe also advised them to wear light clothes and take cold baths as much as possible.\nThe maternal health experts urged pregnant women to avoid walking in the sun, take water intermittently and stay in well-ventilated areas during this period.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says heat waves happen when the temperature is higher than usual for several days.\nIt noted that heat waves can be extremely uncomfortable and pose serious health risks for infants, children, pregnant women and the elderly.\nThe don also said walking in the sun for too long should be discouraged, noting that if such occurs, water should be taken intermittently.\nAn Honorary Consultant Obstetrician Gynaecologist at the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital, Prof Ishaq Abdul, said that the body of pregnant women needs 30 per cent more water due to the increase in blood volume, noting that dehydration caused by the heat wave can negatively affect their body mechanisms.\nHe urged pregnant women to avoid walking in the sun during heat waves,\u201cIn mild forms, there might not be any problem as a pregnant woman can survive but there is a need to drink water intermittently and avoid the heat. Walking about in the heat can compound dehydration, especially if there is already so much water loss while indoors.\u201d\nAbdul urged communities and families to support pregnant women by ensuring that they have access to a cool environment at home and workplace.\n\u201cHeat wave is a serious issue and there is a need to make the society better in terms of having constant electricity supply so that there will be fans and cooling systems in homes and offices,\u201dhe added.\nAbdul advised parents and caregivers to give children more water during this period, warning them to avoid giving juices because it can lead to diarrhoea.         "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. So that\u2019s a better argument to put, rather than saying that heatwaves worsen hypertension.\u201d",

        "Title": "Heatwave: Dermatologist advises Nigerians on safety measures",
        "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

        "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones.         "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

Walking about in the heat can compound dehydration, especially if there is already so much water loss while indoors.\u201d\nAbdul urged communities and families to support pregnant women by ensuring that they have access to a cool environment at home and workplace.\n\u201cHeat wave is a serious issue and there is a need to make the society better in terms of having constant electricity supply so that there will be fans and cooling systems in homes and offices,\u201dhe added.\nAbdul advised parents and caregivers to give children more water during this period, warning them to avoid giving juices because it can lead to diarrhoea.         "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. So that\u2019s a better argument to put, rather than saying that heatwaves worsen hypertension.\u201d",

        "Title": "Heatwave can trigger miscarriage, premature delivery, experts warn",
        "Full_Content": "According to maternal experts, the risk of miscarriage, early labour and preterm delivery is heightened during heat waves.\nREAD ALSO:Heatwave: Avoid exhaustion, dehydration- physician warns\nA professor and Consultant Obstetrician and Gynaecologist at the University of Ilorin, Kwara State, Adegboyega Fawole, said that heat waves have more adverse effects on pregnant women and children than non-pregnant women and adults.\nHe stated that children have small body surfaces and weight and when exposed to heat waves would suffer dehydration.\nFawole said,\u201cA pregnant woman has a body surface that is at that time going through some changes that will make her need more water than when she was not pregnant. Pregnant women get dehydrated easily and quickly.\n\u201cFor pregnant women in their first trimester, extreme heat waves could cause changes in the system where the body is forming the baby.\n\u201cThis period is the time that the organs are formed, when the foetus is ill, there is a higher risk of miscarriage and early birth, which might make the outcome of the pregnancy unpalatable to the mother.\n\u201cFor the baby born prematurely, it causes more difficulty in care as cost and survival is always guarded depending on the age.\u201d\nThe don urged pregnant women during this period to work in a well-ventilated and cool environment and refrain from walking in the sun.\nHe also advised them to wear light clothes and take cold baths as much as possible.\nThe maternal health experts urged pregnant women to avoid walking in the sun, take water intermittently and stay in well-ventilated areas during this period.\nThe United Nations Children\u2019s Fund says heat waves happen when the temperature is higher than usual for several days.\nIt noted that heat waves can be extremely uncomfortable and pose serious health risks for infants, children, pregnant women and the elderly.\nThe don also said walking in the sun for too long should be discouraged, noting that if such occurs, water should be taken intermittently.\nAn Honorary Consultant Obstetrician Gynaecologist at the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital, Prof Ishaq Abdul, said that the body of pregnant women needs 30 per cent more water due to the increase in blood volume, noting that dehydration caused by the heat wave can negatively affect their body mechanisms.\nHe urged pregnant women to avoid walking in the sun during heat waves,\u201cIn mild forms, there might not be any problem as a pregnant woman can survive but there is a need to drink water intermittently and avoid the heat. Walking about in the heat can compound dehydration, especially if there is already so much water loss while indoors.\u201d\nAbdul urged communities and families to support pregnant women by ensuring that they have access to a cool environment at home and workplace.\n\u201cHeat wave is a serious issue and there is a need to make the society better in terms of having constant electricity supply so that there will be fans and cooling systems in homes and offices,\u201dhe added.\nAbdul advised parents and caregivers to give children more water during this period, warning them to avoid giving juices because it can lead to diarrhoea.         "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. So that\u2019s a better argument to put, rather than saying that heatwaves worsen hypertension.\u201d",

        "Title": "Heatwave: Dermatologist advises Nigerians on safety measures",
        "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

        "Title": "Egypt plans power cuts due to heatwave",
        "Full_Content": "Egypt has announced a series of measures, including planned power cuts, to cope with the growing energy consumption caused by the intense heat wave sweeping the country.\nIn a televised address on 6thAugust, Prime Minister Mustafa al-Madbouly called on the private sector to take similar measures, saying that civil servants who do not work in a job in contact with the public will work from home one day a week for a month in order to relieve the electricity grids.\nTo cope with rising energy consumption across the country, planned power cuts are expected to last one or two hours a day at most, he added.\nThey are expected to continue until the end of the current heatwave, which has seen temperatures exceed 45 degrees this week in some parts of the country.\nThe government began implementing the cuts last week, urging residents not to use lifts at certain times of the day.\nThis measure sparked a wave of discontent on social networks, with many complaining that the power cuts, often at the hottest times of the day, lasted for more than two hours and occurred only once a week.\nEgypt\u2019s economy has been undermined by galloping inflation and repeated currency depreciations, which have affected purchasing power and the ability to import essential goods.\nA similar energy crisis during the presidency of Islamist Mohamed Morsi in 2013 sparked widespread anger and protests before he was deposed by the army.\nIn 2015, the Egyptian authorities had struck a deal with Germany\u2019s Siemens to build three major power plants, with investments estimated at six billion euros with the aim of doubling the country\u2019s electricity production.\nSince then, Egypt has had to contend with the depletion of its foreign exchange reserves and a growing debt, exacerbated in particular by Russia\u2019s invasion of Ukraine.\nAfricanews/Hauwa M.",

        "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. So that\u2019s a better argument to put, rather than saying that heatwaves worsen hypertension.\u201d",

        "Title": "Heatwave: Dermatologist advises Nigerians on safety measures",
        "Full_Content": "A Consultant Dermatologist, Dr Folakemi Cole-Adeife, has urged Nigerians to pay special attention to how they feel in the face of extreme heat being experienced across the country.\nREAD ALSO:Dermatologist warns against consistent use of chemical hair relaxers\nCole-Adeife, who works at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, told the Newsmen on Thursday, that extreme heat could be dangerous, leading to heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\nShe said:\u201cNigerians need to stay informed on weather forecasts and heat advisories. They need to be aware of the signs of heat-related illnesses such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke.\n\u201cRemember that extreme heat can be dangerous, So, If you or someone else is experiencing symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, confusion or inability to walk or talk properly, it is essential to seek medical help immediately.\n\u201cHeat-related illnesses can escalate quickly and it could be life-threatening, so early intervention is crucial.\u201d\nCole-Adeife highlighted certain measures to protect oneself and others from heat-related health emergencies like heat exhaustion or heat stroke.\n\u201cStay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, even if you do not feel thirsty. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently. Avoid dark-coloured or thick clothing. These are some tips people can take to stay safe during the heatwave,\u201dshe said.\nThe Dermatologist urged Nigerians to limit outdoor activities during peak sun hours (usually between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.) and Identify public places like shopping malls with air conditioning, where one could escape the heat.\nShe said it was important to use sun protection items such as hat to protect the face and neck as well as sunscreen to protect the skin from harmful Ultraviolet (UV) rays.\n\u201cNow is not the time to use too many skin care products. Stick to soap, a lightweight moisturizer or none. Then, keep an eye on elderly family members, neighbours, children, and those with pre-existing health conditions, as they are more susceptible to heat-related illnesses. Check up on them regularly and encourage them to avoid going outdoors for too long and when indoors they should leave windows and doors open and use fans,\u201dshe advised.\nNAN/Wumi",

        "Title": "Heatwave won\u2019t worsen hypertension \u2013 Cardiac society",
        "Full_Content": "The National President of the Nigerian Cardiac Society, Professor Augustine Odili, says the recent climate change resulting in heatwaves during the day and at night, cannot worsen hypertension in peopling battling with the condition.\nREAD ALSO:Over 3 of 10 Nigerians unaware they are hypertensive \u2013 Cardiac society\nOdili, a consultant cardiologist, stated that heatwaves could lead to dehydration and other heat-related ailments.\nHe reiterated that heatwave would not worsen hypertension outcomes.\nAccording to him, the present heatwave has no different impact on people with hypertension than it does on those without the illness.\nHe explained that contrary to popular belief, heat would not lower high blood pressure, adding that cold weather was more dangerous for people with hypertension.\nThe Nigerian Meteorological Agency had advised people to drink more water and stay hydrated, avoid more consumption of alcoholic beverages and caffeinated beverages, reduce intake of food rich in proteins because they increase metabolic activities as fresh foods and fruits are better alternatives, stay indoors between 12 noon and 4:30pm, take a cold bath before going to bed at night, and monitor their blood pressure always, among others.\nOdili said,\u201cThe issue of heatwave is not necessarily only those with hypertension. Heatwaves can affect anybody and I think that\u2019s the first thing people need to know.\n\u201cHeatwave is not likely to worsen hypertension. If anything will worsen hypertension, it will be cold and not heat.\n\u201cAnd it\u2019s important we make it known to people because there is a completely wrong notion about hypertension. So, any little thing that happens in society, they will say it will worsen hypertension.\n\u201cThere is so much stress in the country, everywhere is hot, and there is no power supply. Now, people will say that if you are hypertensive and there is a heatwave, you are in trouble, it\u2019s not true.\n\u201cWhat happens with the heatwave is that, yes, it\u2019s quite hot and people are likely to sweat more than before, and then it can cause dehydration, but it will not make hypertension worse.\n\u201cBut if we have a serious winter, if somebody is not taking his antihypertensive medication and he has a serious cold, the blood pressure would go up more than during the heat period. \u201d\nThe cardiologist pointed out that people working in the sun and not taking enough water might suffer kidney stones.\nThe physician stressed the need for people to drink enough water so that their urine will not become concentrated and predisposes them to kidney stones.\nHe added,\u201cThe area that I will even want to talk about is drinking water and avoiding things like kidney stones, especially people who work under the sun.\n\u201cPeople need to drink more water so that their urine will not become concentrated and then predisposing them to kidney stones. Aim for 2.5 to 3.5 litres of water daily and avoid drinks with caffeine, high sugar content or alcohol, as they can contribute to dehydration.\n\u201cUse fans and air conditioning to cool indoor spaces. Take cool baths frequently to lower your body temperature. However, baths should be without soap if more than two times a day to avoid drying out the skin.\n\u201cOpen windows at home to allow for cross ventilation. Invest in a rechargeable fan, considering the concurrent electricity shortage in the country.\n\u201cWear loose, lightweight, and light-coloured clothing to reflect the sun and allow your body to cool efficiently.
